journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: A robust adaptive hybrid force/position control scheme of two planar manipulators handling an unknown object interacting with an environment

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
3Faculty of Computer Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Enghelab Street- Hafez Street, Tehran, Iran. email: rmohajer@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: This paper presents a robust hybrid force/position control scheme of two cooperative manipulators handling an unknown object interacting with an unknown environment. The uncertainty of the object is considered in the weight, length, and the position of centre of mass (COM). The environment is assumed to have an unknown but high stiffness. A hybrid force/position control algorithm is designed for the known system and environment case. The exponential convergence of the position and the interaction force with the environment is proved using the Lyapunov direct method. Similarly, in the unknown object and environment case, and in the presence of bounded disturbances on the robots and the object, an adaptive sliding mode hybrid force/position control scheme is designed. The asymptotic convergence of the object’s position and the constraint force is guaranteed using the proposed control methodology. The internal forces and moments between the object and robots are controlled independently of the object’s motion and environmental interaction forces. Simulation results confirm the performance and effectiveness of the suggested control methodologies.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Recently, cooperative systems have been considered by scientists and researchers due to their indispensable advantages. In the grasping domain and the manipulation of objects, cooperative systems are capable of grasping and moving objects of various shapes and weights. Hence, these systems can be very advantageous in grasping and handling heavy objects with unknown shape. For example, in the industrial automation domain, cooperative systems are used for assembling parts of a system. Cooperative teleoperation is a new subject that can be used in telesurgery to help surgeons to perform difficult surgical operations with an acceptable level of precision at distances far from the operating room.

However, due to extreme non-linearity, control methodologies for the stabilization of cooperative robotic systems should be robust against system uncertainties and disturbances. This issue complicates the design of a control scheme for such systems and some simplifications in the modelling might be necessary.
There are three main strategies for centralized cooperative robot control [1]:

In the master/slave control strategy [2–4], one or multiple robots are considered as master and the others work as slaves. The environmental effects are not usually taken into consideration in this strategy and an artificial symmetry is imposed on the slave robots. In coordinated motion strategy, the object’s grasping and manipulation is achieved through control of the robots’ end effectors (EEs) [5–7]. However, this methodology is not effective in constrained systems, where external forces are exerted on the object. In the object’s motion strategy [1, 8] which is used in this paper, the system dynamics are obtained based on the object’s dynamic parameters and the object is controlled directly. Therefore, there is no need for the robot’s dynamics.

There is an alternative control strategy to the centralized control approach, called decentralized control [7, 9–11]. In this approach, each robot is controlled separately and independently of the kinematics and dynamics of the other robots. This property helps in the design of a control scheme with a smaller computation load than in the centralized control approach. However, it has some disadvantages, such as the unknown load distribution between the robots.

Tomizuka and Pagilla [5], presented an adaptive control methodology for a system of two robot arms handling an unknown object in free motion. Moreover, the authors introduced an adaptive hybrid force/position control strategy, which can control both the motion and force of a constrained cooperative system [6]. Nevertheless, this paper considers only dynamic uncertainties (no kinematic uncertainty) and the system dynamics is obtained in the joint space of the robots. Zribi et al. [12, 13] had success in designing two different robust and adaptive control strategies in the task space which could control an unknown system consisting of two cooperative manipulators handling an object interacting with the environment. However, uncertainties in the dynamic parameters of the object alone is considered in these papers. Sirouspour [4] presented cooperative control schemes in teleoperation systems for the first time. Although a robust controller is suggested in this work, the tool or object’s dimension, centre of gravity, and configuration are assumed to be known. The control problem of cooperative systems has also been studied in some papers such as in references [6], [12], and [14]. Nevertheless, to the best of the authors’ knowledge, no work has been reported in the literature so far that concerns the case of an unknown object’s dynamics and kinematics parameters. There are different methodologies in controlling cooperative systems [15], such as impedance control, hybrid control, and intelligent approaches. Because the hybrid force/position control algorithm separates the force and motion subspaces and controls each subspace independently, it has become a focus of interest recently. However, it has some disadvantages as well. For example, it is not possible to completely decompose force and motion subspaces if they have a direct effect on each other. On the other hand, in some assembly strategies using a hybrid force/position control scheme might impose high rate switching on the control signal which leads to system instability. Hybrid force/position control has various methodologies that have been mentioned in different books [15–17].

Two distinct contacts can be introduced between the EEs of the robots and the grasped object: rigid contact and rolling contact. Each of these assumptions imposes a different kinematic holonomic constraint on the system. In the rigid contact assumption [5, 7, 12, 18], the EE of the robot and the object are fixed relative to each other and the robot exerts a torque on the object. On the other hand, in the rolling contact assumption [11, 19, 20], the robot does not exert any torque on the object and only applies normal and frictional forces to it. As a result, the system degrees of freedom (DOFs) and the constraint conditions imposed on the system increase. The grasping stability is a challenging issue itself and has been taken into consideration in the literature recently, especially for hand finger robots [19–21].

The contribution of this paper lies in the design of a robust adaptive hybrid control methodology for a cooperative system consisting of an object with kinematic and dynamic uncertainties interacting with an unknown but stiff environment and subjected to some bounded disturbances. Moreover, the asymptotic convergence of the interaction force with the environment (constraint force for brevity) and the object’s position is proved for this control strategy. This guarantees the desired performance of the suggested controller for a time-variable desired position and constraint force signals.

This paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the reduced dynamics of the cooperative system is obtained in the task space based on the object’s dynamic parameters. In section 3 the hybrid force/position control scheme in the known and unknown cases for the object and the environment is given. In section 4, a control methodology for independent control of the internal forces and moments between the robots and the object is given. In section 5, the effectiveness of the proposed controllers are verified using a simulation in MATLAB. Concluding remarks are given in section 6.

sec.title: 2 Dynamic Equations of Motion
sec.p: It is assumed that the two robots have similar dynamic and kinematic parameters and have six DOFs. The grasped object is assumed to be in contact with a constrained wall. For simplicity, in this paper the effect of friction between the object and the wall is neglected and only normal forces are exerted from the wall on the object. The following assumptions are also made.

list-item.p: (A1) The geometry of the contact is known.
(A2) The contact between each EE and the object is rigid.
(A3) The robots will not be configured in singular condition.

sec.title: 2.1 Dynamics of the robots
sec.p: The schematic of the coordinate frames and exerted forces on the object is depicted in Fig. 1. The dynamics of each robot can be written as [22]

sec.title: 2.2 Object dynamics
sec.p: The dynamics of the object can be written as

where mo is the object’s mass, Mo is its inertia matrix, Co is the matrix of Coriolis and centrifugal forces, go is the vector of gravitational forces, do is the vector of disturbances (unwanted forces and moments) exerted on the object and fo is the vector of external forces and moments exerted on it. The latter consists of two terms, fho and feo, which are the external forces and moments from the robots and the constrained surface, respectively. Moreover, To is the rotation matrix that transforms the object frame to the base coordinate frame. It should be noted that

Now, fh and fho and also X·o and X·ei are related according to (i=1,2)
where Jo is the grasping matrix

The environmental forces exerted on the object can be computed from (6), where λc is a relevant m×1 vector, with m being the number of contact points with the environment and N is a matrix whose columns are the unit vectors determining the orientation of the exerted forces

In this paper it is assumed that the object is always in contact with the environment. Some selective matrices should be used in order to decompose the object’s motion and the interaction forces spaces. To this end, bases of the force control subspace are defined by the columns of a (6×m) selective matrix called Sf. Similarly, bases of the motion subspace are introduced by the columns of the matrix Sv, which is a 6×(6−m) selective matrix and lies in the null space of Sf, that is

It should be noted that the selective matrices are responsible for decomposing the dynamics of the system into two independent subspaces: motion subspace and force subspace. In our system, we have assumed that the object would always be in contact with the environment and as a result there are always two selective matrices to decompose the force and motion subspaces. Moreover, the dynamics of the system are written based on the position, velocity, and acceleration of the object. Hence, the selective matrices depend on the position of the object. The dimensions of these matrices depend fully on the DOFs of the whole system (not each manipulator) and the dimension of the force and motion subspaces. The determination of these matrices is straightforward and explained in a simple way in reference [16].
It is clear that fh has two important effects.

list-item.p: Movement of the object with a specific velocity and acceleration.
Grasping of the object in order to maintain the contact between the object and manipulators, which does not affect its motion.

sec.p: Thus, it is possible to decompose fh into two orthogonal subspaces such as

where fint=Pfh is the vector of internal forces and moments for grasping the object and has no effect in the motion of the object. The matrix P which lies in the orthogonal space of (JoT)† and decomposes the force space, can be obtained as [23]
where (JoT)† is the weighted pseudo-inverse of the matrix JoT and is defined in
in which A is an arbitrary matrix. The problem investigated in this paper is planar. Hence, the interaction force acting on the environment in each direction (λci) can be computed as

where δxi is the displacement of the object in the exerted force direction and kci is the stiffness of the environment. Although it is assumed that λci can be measured using a force sensor, the environment stiffness is unknown and only an estimate of it is available. Nevertheless, due to the stiff environment assumption it is logical to assume that the estimated stiffness of the environment, satisfies the relationship
Now, by some algebraic manipulation we can get the equations
where c is the compliance of the environment. It is evident that by decomposition of fh into two independent forces fho and fint, it is possible to design a controller for each of them.

sec.title: 2.3 The overall dynamics of the cooperative system
sec.p: Due to the rigidity of the contact between the object and manipulators (assumption (A2)) and by means of system kinematics and dynamics (equations (3) and (4)), the overall dynamics of the cooperative system can be written as

where um is the control signal for the motion and the interaction force and uf is the control signal for the internal forces and moments. Thus, the control signal can be obtained as u=um+uf. Moreover, v is the transformed form of the control signal um. Considering the orthogonality of Sv and Sf, (15) can be decomposed into two independent equations

where Pv is a square matrix which projects to the motion control subspace. Equations (16) and (17) represent the motion subspace and the force subspace dynamics, respectively. Equation (17) just describes the dynamics of the force subspace (y-direction in this problem). Moreover, there are cλ··c and cλ·c in (17), in which c is the compliance of the environment. sec.title: 3 Controller Design
sec.p: The system investigated in this paper consists of two 3-DOF planar manipulators handling an object with known geometry (e.g. circular) that exert a controlled force on a stiff wall which is the constrained surface of the workspace (however, this is not a restriction and the presented methodology can be extended to 6-DOF robots as well).

It is noted that the investigated cooperative system has 9 DOFs (two 3-DOF robots and one 3-DOF object). The constraints between the EEs of the robots and the grasped object (all of which are considered to be rigid) have reduced 6-DOFs of the system. Therefore, the cooperative system has three DOFs in the free motion case. The reduced degrees of freedom of the system would produce the internal forces lying in the null space of the motion subspace and are controlled in the proposed methodology. In fact, the stacked dynamics of the cooperative robots (equation (3)) contain the internal forces. Using this and the control signal um these forces can be controlled readily through the proposed strategy in section (4). In any event, these forces have no effect on the position of the object and as a result do not affect the definition of the selective matrices.
For simplicity, there is only one direction acting on the environment, hence, m=1. Therefore, Sf,Sv, and Pv can be obtained as
The block diagram of the developed hybrid control scheme is depicted in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Block diagram of the designed hybrid control strategy

sec.title: 3.1 The known system case
sec.p: In this part, the object and the stiffness of the environment in addition to the manipulators parameters are assumed to be known and there are no disturbances on the system. The control signals designed for the motion and force control subsystems are some non-linear feedback linearization proportional–derivative (PD) controllers that are given as

where v·hod is the desired acceleration of the object, Mc=cmc and λ··d is the second derivative of the desired interaction force acting on the environment. The object’s velocity error is v~ho=vho−vd and the environment force error is λ~=λc−λd. Moreover, KpvandKdv are the proportional and derivative gains, respectively and are positive definite matrices. The control signal (19) is designed for control of the force subsystem and Kdc and Kpc are positive constants. Since the derivative of the environment force is not measurable, a relationship is derived for the estimation of λ·c based on the kinematic equations between the object and the constrained surface and also between the robots and the object [16]
The following theorems summarize the main purpose of this section.

Consider the motion control subsystem dynamics (16), the control signal (18), and assume that there are no disturbances on the cooperative system. If all of the parameters of the control signal (18) are known, the object’s position error converges to zero exponentially, that is
The error dynamics of the motion control subspace are obtained from (18) and (16)
Thus, ∫0tv~ho converges to zero exponentially and the rate of convergence is the real part of

Consider the force control subsystem (17), the control signal (19), and assume that there are no disturbances on the cooperative system. If all of the parameters of the control signal (19) are known, the constraint force error converges to zero exponentially, that is
The force subsystem error dynamics is obtained from (19) and (17)
Moreover, the rate of convergence is the real part of

However, this is not the case in a realistic problem, in which the object’s kinematic and dynamic parameters and the stiffness of the environment are to be generally unknown. The next section considers the unknown system case.

sec.title: 3.2 The unknown system case
sec.p: Unlike in the previous section, here the object’s kinematic and dynamic parameters and the stiffness of the environment are considered to be unknown. Moreover, the robots and the object are subjected to some bounded disturbances. Thus, a model-based adaptive sliding mode control scheme is designed for each subsystem, based on Lyapunov’s direct method

where λ~^·=λ^·c−λ·d is the estimated derivative of the interaction force error, c^ is the estimated compliance of the environment, Sat(.) is the saturation function and ⊙ is the element-wise product. The adaptive control algorithm (21) is designed for the motion subsystem control, in which Kph and Kdh are the proportional and derivative control gains, respectively, and are constant and positive definite matrices. The adaptation laws that are used in the estimation of the unknown parameters of the control signal (21) are obtained as (23). The derivation of these laws is based on Lyapunov’s direct method in which the updating laws of the unknown parameters are defined such that the derivative of the Lyapunov function used in the stability analysis of the system becomes nonpositive

where vr=vho−γh∫v~hodτ is the reference signal for motion control subspace, mij is the ijth element of the known matrix TTMT, T=[I6×6Jo2Jo1−1]12×6=cte, and Eij∈R5×5 is a square matrix, whose ijth elements are one and the others are zero. Similarly, cij is the ijth element of the known matrix TTCT, gi is the ith element of the vector TTG, and g is the gravitational constant. The other parameters are defined in Appendix 1.

Moreover, Kh is a constant positive definite matrix, d1∈R5+ and d2∈R+ are the upper bounds of the disturbances dh and dc, respectively, and γh and γc are some constant positive numbers which are used in the definition of the sliding surfaces. The motion control subsystem sliding surface is Sh=v~ho+γh∫v~hodτ and the corresponding force control subsystem sliding surface is Sc=cλ~·+γcλ~. The adaptive control signal (22) is used in the force subsystem control. In this control signal, Kc, Kpc, and Kdc are some constant positive gains and S^c=λ~^·+γcλ~. Furthermore, the unknown parameters of this control signal are estimated through (24), in which γmo and γmc are positive constants called the adaptation gains of the estimation laws
Since the environment’s stiffness is unknown, only an estimate of the derivative of the constraint force might be obtained
where k^c is the estimated stiffness of the environment. Now, considering (12) and (20), the following is concluded

After substituting (21) into (16), the dynamic equation of the motion subsystem closed-loop error (26) is obtained. The force control subsystem closed-loop error (27) is also achieved by putting (22) into (17)
Now, the main aim of the paper is summarized in the two following theorems.

Consider the force control subsystem (17), the control signal (22), and the adaptation law (24). Now, if the control gains Kpc and Kdc are chosen properly such that the inequalities (28) are satisfied, then the unknown control parameters estimation error would remain bounded and the contact force error, λ~c and its derivative converge to zero asymptotically
where λmin{A},λmax{A} are the minimum and maximum eigenvalues of the matrix A, respectively.

By putting the adaptation law (24) into (30), taking into account Property (2.3), and provided that (28) is satisfied, the following inequality is obtained

Therefore, λ~, λ~·, and m~o are bounded. Moreover, according to (27), the boundedness of λ·d and λ··d and the property (2.3), λ~·· is also bounded. Hence, λ~ and λ~· are uniformly continuous. Finally it is concluded from Barbalat’s lemma [24] that

Consider the motion control subsystem (16), the control signal (21), and the adaptation laws (23). Now, if the control gains Kph and Kdh are chosen properly such that inequality (32) are satisfied, then the unknown control parameters estimation error would remain bounded and the object’s position error and its derivative converge to zero asymptotically
The proof of this theorem is given in Appendix 2.

sec.title: 4 The Internal Forces And Moments Control
sec.p: The control objective is to confine the forces exerted by the robots on the object to prevent any damage to it and at the same time provide a secure grasping that gives assurance that the object will be held securely during manipulation. The dynamics of the cooperative system can be rewritten as (33) which is obtained from (3), (5), and (8)

since the force fh can be measured through sensing by a load cell, and the matrix P is known, the internal forces is assumed to be measurable. Nevertheless, in case there are no sensor devices for force measurement, the internal forces can be observed through a non-linear observer such as an extended Kalman filter [25].
The control signal in the task space, v, is computed based on computation of the control signals vc and vh, that are computed according to (16) and (17) given as

Since the matrix T1 depends only on the relative position of the contact points of the robots with the object, its value is already known. The control signal um (which is used in the position and interaction force control) has been designed so far. Next, the control signal uf which carries the burden of controlling the grasping force of the object, will be determined. However, first, the contribution of each robot from the control signal um, that is um1 and um2, should be specified. To this end, a cost function Ju is defined to obtain the optimum values for um1 and um2 [5]

With the signals umi, i={1,2} and the robots Jacobian matrices, Ji, it is possible to determine the optimum values of the joint control torques τi. In order to control the internal forces, a proportional–integral (PI) control signal with a compensating feed forward term is proposed as

where fintd is the desired internal forces and moments Kfp and KfI are the proportional and integral control gains, respectively that are some constant positive definite matrices. The following theorem illustrates the boundedness of the internal forces using the control signal u.
By applying the control signal (37) to the cooperative system (33), the internal forces errors will remain bounded.
After substitution of the control signal (37) into (33), the internal forces dynamic error equation is obtained as
where η is a function of the object and robots parameters. According to the results of the theorems (3.4) and (3.3), the right-hand side of equation (38) is bounded. Hence, efint is bounded and if
then
To this end, it is necessary that the unknown control parameters converge to their respective real values.

sec.title: 5 Simulation Results
sec.p: The robot manipulators used in this simulation are 3 DOFs and planar. The grasped object is a circular disc of radius 20 cm and mass 1 kg. It is assumed that the object’s mass, diameter, and the centre of mass position are unknown. Uncertainty for each parameter is assumed to be 50 per cent. The utilized robots are similar and their kinematic and dynamic parameters are given as in Table 1.

caption.p: The robot parameters in the simulation

sec.p: In Table 1, mi, li, and Ii are the mass, length, and inertia of the ith link of the robot, respectively. The constrained surface is a horizontal wall in yc=−1.2m and its stiffness is equal to kc=104[N/m] which is estimated to be k^c=6000 N/m. The simulation has been performed in the Simulink environment of MATLAB. The configuration of the robots, the object and the constrained wall in the simulation are depicted in Fig. 3.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the simulated cooperative system

sec.p: The desired position, interaction force acting on the environment and the internal forces are
Furthermore, the disturbances that are used in the simulation are

The simulation was performed for the uncertain object and environment using the control signals developed in sections 3.1 and 3.2 and the results compared. For better comparison, the same proportional and derivative control gains were selected for the simulation in each control strategy. The object’s horizontal position error variation during the simulation is depicted in Fig. 4. It shows that unlike the known case control strategy, the object’s x-position in the unknown case control algorithm has fully converged to its desired value in about 2 s. Similarly, the object’s rotational position and the interaction force with the environment have converged to their respective desired values in the unknown case control algorithm as shown in Figs 5 and 6. In comparison, due to the uncertainty of the control parameters and existence of the disturbances on the robots and the environment, the convergence of the control outputs in the known case control algorithm is poor relative to the unknown case algorithm (Figs 4 to 6) which confirms the effectiveness of the control methodology presented in section (3.2). Hence, it is obvious from the results that the control signals (21) and (22) are robust against the uncertainties in the environment and grasped object and the robots and environmental disturbances.

caption.p: The object’s position error in the x direction (m)

sec.p: Based on Lemma 5.1 of reference [26], if the equilibrium point of the nominal system is (uniformly) exponentially stable, then the perturbed system will be (uniformly) asymptotically stable. Hence, by implementing the control algorithm of the known object case on the unknown perturbed system, the cooperative system remains stable because the exponential stability of the nominal system is verified before. This property is shown in Figs 4 to 6.

Although the estimated control parameters remain bounded, they do not necessarily converge to their respective real values, unless the persistency excitation condition of the estimator input signal is satisfied [24]. However, usually this does not happen in the adaptive control of complicated systems like this. In this respect, Fig. 8 shows the variation of the horizontal component of the estimated value of r→1. Moreover, the internal forces errors variation remain bounded but do not converge to zero as displayed in Fig. 7. The optimal control torques of the first robot joints that are computed from (35) are shown in Fig. 9. Both Figs 7 and 9 refer to the unknown case control strategy simulation.

caption.p: The ‘x’ component error of the estimated value of r1
The control torques of the first robot joints

sec.title: 6 Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, first the dynamics of a constrained cooperative system consisting of two robot arms handling an object interacting with an environment is developed. The object’s contact with the environment is assumed to be compliant and bilateral. Then, the reduced dynamics of the whole system is obtained based on the object’s dynamic parameters such that the internal forces for grasping the object were hidden in the obtained dynamics. The motion and force control subsystems of the reduced dynamics are decomposed as well. At the control stage, first a non-linear hybrid force/position control scheme for independent control of the object’s position and the interaction force with the environment in a fully known cooperative system without any disturbances is developed. Then, with the uncertainty assumption in the environment and the object’s kinematic and dynamic parameters, a robust adaptive hybrid force/position controller is designed. Using the Lyapunov direct method, the exponential and asymptotic convergence of the object’s position and interaction force with the environment is proved in the known and unknown system case control strategies, respectively. Finally, a control strategy is suggested for the control of internal forces and moments with the objective of secure grasping and also boundedness of the grasping forces. At the simulation stage, the effectiveness and performance of the proposed control schemes verified through a simulation in MATLAB. The simulation was performed for a cooperative system consisting of an unknown object and environment subjected to some bounded disturbances. The simulation results of using the two control strategies in the explained modelled system were compared. The results confirmed the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed robust adaptive hybrid control algorithm in control of such unknown cooperative systems. Future work will concentrate on the modelling of the rolling contact between the object and robots instead of the rigid contact assumption. Furthermore, the assumption of the unknown robot link dynamic parameters and design of a non-linear observer for the robot joint velocity measurements are also some issues that will be considered in the future.

sec.title: Proof of Theorem (3.4)
sec.p: Let us define a Lyapunov function Vh as
The variables used in V1 are the unknown parameters of the control signal (21) and are introduced as

Each of these parameters errors is defined as [~o]=[^o]−[o] and {γi,γik,γm,γmx,αjj,γd,βj,γdd} are some positive numbers which define the update rate of the estimated parameters and are called adaptation gains.
After differentiation of the Lyapunov function and placement from (26), the following equation is obtained
Now, by the substitution of the adaptation laws from (23) into (40), if the control gains Kph and Kdh satisfy the conditions (32), and using the property (2.2), the following is obtained

Thus, eh∈L2∩L∞ and η∈L∞ where η contains the estimated control parameters. Due to the property (2) and the aforementioned conclusions, all of the elements of the right-hand side of (26) and CRv~ho are bounded and as a result v~·ho is bounded. Therefore, ∫v~hodτ and v~ho are uniformly continuous. Finally, it is concluded from Barbalat’s lemma that
